title: Thursday, 22nd February, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am

RA holla
Soundbuy Morning

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever.

rwl hi
Miss Piggy Ust. 10s gonna hit 3%, morning.

Dan, I think, is joining today.

of determination, resolve, etc

RA striking resemblance

11:08 am

............ yep.

DM11:09am

The Conservative party isn't

DM11:09am

It has just sent out a fundraiser to members asking them to help pay for Campaign Managers

rwl IMHO - people appear to be over confident and too relaxed about the B word
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Uh-oh.

DM11:10am

The ostensible reason is the local elections coming up later this year

Miss Piggy What will Brenda from Bristol say?
Lemmy Too relaxed for me, several scenarios could see UK government collapse, eg DUP pull out because of Brexit and border issues, government loses a vote over Brexit, Tories write enough letters to the 22 committee etc etc
DM11:11am

But, what's the right phrasing here

11:11 am
DM11:11am

Kate understands central office is effectively on a war footing here, in case it has to fight an election

DM11:12am

The campaign managers can then be kept on, in case the internal tensions within the party reach breaking point

IslandDweller Many business leaders seem relaxed because they appear to think "no one would be so stupid as to leave without a deal" - I think they underestimate the lack of calibre in this cabinet
DM11:13am

They don't want an election in the same way Turkeys don't thrill at the sound of jingle bells

BBOC Can't remember who it was, but someone very sensibly pointed out that there hasn't been a Tory politician in living memory that wasn't eventually backstabbed by their own party. Have a feeling that May will end up just like the rest of them
Fox Conn sounds very bullish on Centrica prospects and growth
chad_john NOT ANOTHER ONE
Miss Piggy It is not that the cabinet is stupid, it is becuase the situation is impossible
fortyeight Are JRM IDS and the DUP really mad enough to want an election?
wayneJ Can I offer up an RNS today that has what looks like a profit warning hidden in paragraph 10?
IslandDweller Miss Piggy - or perhaps it's an impossible situation made worse by a useless cabinet...
11:14 am

But the EU 27 are supposed to be getting some sort of deal/proposal/outline in October, and it seems like the politicos are a lot more worried about the potential for it to go a bit wrong than markets, investors, general observers

British Gas owner Centrica expresses ‘deep regret’ over poor results

BE11:19am

Deep regret over hitting expectations and holding the divi, which is the main point on which it's rallied.

wayneJ So I would suggest in para 21 of its RNS today Northgate has hidden a 25% PBT warning?
Miss Piggy Impossible because of Parliamenntart arithmetic, need a convincing result one way or the other
11:19 am
BE11:19am

I guess Centrica has to sound apologetic at all times, since it's a political football.

BE11:19am

RBC can summarise where we are.

Swedish Chef As I (still) hold Centrica my market opinions are worthless.
BE11:20am

CNA has released its full year results this morning which reported an adjusted EPS of 12.6p/sh (2016: 16.8p/sh), which was in line with consensus estimates given the updated guidance of ~12.5p/sh released in November. 2017 has been a disappointing year for CNA with Centrica Business underperforming in both the UK and North America, whilst the growth segments of Distributed Energy & Power and Connected Homes saw increased losses.

RA Any thoughts on Amazon hitting 1500?
wayneJ How can a company (Northgate) hide a profit warning in para 21?
11:20 am
BE11:20am

For 2018 CNA does not provided specific guidance but are pointing to growth in EBIT for customer facing businesses, higher output for upstream activities (including storage), lower finance charges and higher tax rates.

BE11:21am

Overall, this seems to be at least supportive of RBCe of growth in EPS to 13.8p, and consensus of ~14.0p/sh.

RA @BE FT forecasts look optimistic for Bayer, their QR in 6 days, any thoughts on the pharma industry?
December69 Because analysts generally phone IR before dribbling on
DM11:22am

UBS see positives, which are enough to explain the 5p jump

11:21 am
BE11:22am

(I'm having to break this up into individual sentences because the FT's brilliant spam filter applies on this side of the page as well, which stops the posting of block text.)

BE11:22am

Go on ......

DM11:22am

On top of the new cost target, we see (i) Net Debt is £260m below consensus (+5p per share in a Sum of the Parts view) and at the low (i.e. good) end of the range targeted for a strong inv. grade credit rating; (ii) Adj OCF is guided at £2.1-2.3bn for 2018; large M&A is ruled out; but £0.4bn bonds may be called in 2018 with £25-35m upside to annual interest costs; (iii) DPS confirmed at 12p and guided flat at this level for 2018 (v. consensus 11.4p); (iv) a modest increase in capex; (v) Centrica stated they are seeking buyers for the UK nuclear stake; (vi) British Gas Standard Tariff currently the lowest of the six large energy firms; total customer account losses slowed to 0.5% since Q3 2017, and within that British Gas Services account volumes had returned to growth.

December69 Re: northgate
11:22 am
DM11:22am

Two negatives

DM11:22am

first, if the one-off benefits in the tax line do not repeat, Centrica could see an effective tax rate above 30% next year, which might offset some of the benefits above

DM11:23am

second, consensus EPS remains c5% above UBSe for 2018 and might need to come down slightly (but on the other hand, as above, consensus Net Debt is too high and DPS is too low, so these may need to be revised positively).

Finster The situation is impossible. The Brexit envisioned was one done into the 1970s and not into today's power blocks. It's not a comfortable "with the US against communism." It's cutthroat US vs EU vs Russia vs Asia vs China. If you don't have critical mass you don't matter at the table.

Also highlight that the PnL impact can't be considered without considering what is happening to the balance sheet - if your PPU is down then u have 100,000 vans whose residual values need to be written down - except the company is avoiding this by holding onto them longer.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Here comes Cazenove.

BE11:36am

Following Barclays’ FY’17 results, we expect cons EPS will likely have to be upgraded materially driven by Revenue, a lower tax rate, higher DPS, despite Q4 coming inline with JPMe and below company cons with a number of exceptional items. The key highlight in our view is CT1 at 13.3%, above expectations (13%) and management indicating a rise in DPS for 2018 to 6.5p (above cons. 5.2p). We believe that there are a number of positives within this update that reinforce our positive view on the shares, in particular on revenue which is 1% above consensus in the two main divisions in Q4 (UK & Intl). Markets revenues have outperformed peers in Q4 and are up y/y in 2018. Tax guidance is positive at mid-20s vs cons 30%. Overall, we are 8%/11% above cons EPS for 2018/19E and call the start of an upgrade cycle; stay OW

BE11:36am

(Pleasingly, Google autocorrect seems to want to change Cazenove to Volcanoes.)

December69 - Sceptic What can go wrong. At 7.5% down everything must be in good health. Rental market margins tighter than ever...demand going towards leasing and 2nd hand...oh well guessing it's another business I don't understand.
11:36 am
DM11:37am

Teeth smile

BE11:37am

And Goldman.

BornCynic Morning - thanks for Centrica BE
BE11:37am

Barclays reported a 42% miss in underlying PBT to company-compiled consensus, driven by lower revenues and higher costs. More importantly however, on the positive side, the group (1) beat on capital (+40 bps vs consensus), driven by lower RWAs, (2) kept capital guidance unchanged at 13.0% (this is in contrast to recent peer commentary of upward pressure on capital) and (3) plans to pay a 6.5p dividend for 2018, above consensus expecations of 5.2p. Further, the group sees current YTD IB revenue trends as higher compared to 1Q17 (both in USD and GBP terms).
All in, we expect the shares to react positively today, as we believe better capital and dividend guidance will likely outweigh the weaker quarterly P&L.

Grouchmonkey @dec out of banks for a while, now, but just beginning to think about a few modest long positions on the basis rising rates= better NIM.

Eclectic interests on the right

BE11:43am

It's a bloody Thursday when I have approximately 17 million companies to boil into this thing -- https://www.ft.com...-9376-4a6390addb44 -- so reading the dense and not entirely transparent updates from a white van company didn't fit into my schedule.

Northgate PLC (NTG:LSE): Last: 324.80, down 26.2 (-7.46%), High: 335.60, Low: 300.00, Volume: 732.33k
Miss Piggy @Island: really? you recommend Southend Airport?
Forester My old credit officer had a favorite saying "never lend to a leasing / rental business"
11:43 am
BE11:43am

They're off, though, and I'll bow to @wayneJ on the right who suggests there's a buried profit warning in there.

BE11:44am

Barclays just sums it up as "messy".

DM11:45am

Not that buried, looking at the presentation

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Today’s statement updates 3Q trading (3mths to 31-Jan-18) as well as announcing a new “fleet optimisation strategy”. Firstly, 3Q trading, where we see the key messages as: (1) 3Q VOH (vehicles on hire) trends leave both the UK and Spain on track to hit management’s previously announced targets for the FY, namely 4Q average VOH being broadly flat yoy in the UK and growth of greater than 10% in Spain; and (2) rental margins are under pressure in the UK (3Q: -1.3pp), and are expected to remain so into FY19 reflecting continued pricing adjustments, but rental margin is improving in Spain (3Q: +3.3pp) driven by operational gearing. Things get a little messier when we turn to the fleet optimization strategy where, following a review of historical fleet holding periods and the current asset register, management have concluded that vehicles in the UK and Spain should be held for “substantially longer than has been the case over recent years” and that disposal profits in recent years have comprised “ever higher volumes of ever younger vehicles at ever lower PPUs” – addressing this to maximize cash returns in the business is absolutely the right thing to do in our view but in the short-term it will result in significant volatility in the P&L as the fleet is aged to the optimal level, impacting planned disposals and purchases as well as likely resulting in yet another depreciation rate change in June.

IslandDweller @Miss Piggy. If you're considering Luton or Stansted, then add Southend to list. Far better experience, and much easier to get to than people think (train every 10 min from L'pool St)
DM11:45am

The new fleet optimisation strategy maximises cash returns and creates a more efficient capital base for the
business. Operational cash generation and EBITDA are not affected. FY18 PBT is, however, expected to reduce by
c.25% versus the £75million reported in prior year

BE11:46am

The statement provides explicit guidance for FY18 PBT which is now guided to be c25% lower than FY17A, indicating PBT of c£56m vs. our previous forecast of £70m (as the statement notes, FY18 EBITDA is unaffected by the fleet optimisation strategy as the change in planned disposals impacts the depreciation charge, not the income generated from rental). For FY19F the picture is more complicated with the likely depreciation changes that lie ahead in June rendering any PBT forecast we make now largely meaningless in four months time; given the uncertainty of the likely scale of any depreciation changes, for now we set our forecasts on the basis of the existing depreciation rates, which results in an FY19F PBT of £41m (previous £71m) but note that a reduction of 1% in the depreciation rate in UK and Spain would result in a combined P&L benefit of c£10m in FY19F. We reduce our PT to 450p (from 600p), equating to 1.2x (from 1.5x prior) tangible NAV.

wayneJ @BE - I was suggesting that saying your PBT is going to be down 20% but putting it in para 21 seems a reasonable definition of buried profit warning? :-)
Shinshin @island - never been to southend...
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Yeah, £56m vs £70 expected sure does look like a warning.

DM11:48am

"The historical approach to disposals has not led to the maximisation of long term shareholder value." Haven't been paying attention, but it doesn't sound great, given the business is basically buying vans and extracting value by renting them

wayneJ Also the analysts seem to have not realised that competing van hire companies with news vans are also available - so to length the ownership duration Northgate's assumptions of rent per day might need to go in a gravitationally induced direction
BE11:48am

It means they were flogging off young vehicles to hit forecasts, right?

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And now, they'll stop doing that?

SoS I ran aground off southend pier - closest I have ever been
BE11:49am

Or at least they'll hold vehicles for three to nine months longer?

Soundbuy Southend - woken up in Southend.........twice.........the train and all that....
wayneJ @BE - yep - but then found they were not reaching the profit expected per van - so now holding the vans for longer. But surely finding that selling vans is not as profitable also raises issues on the balance sheet value
BE11:49am

So you get a re-setting of the depreciation rates? I'm just reading this on the fly so don't trust me here.

11:49 am
DM11:49am

How about this one:

DM11:49am

PPU is a Non-GAAP measure
used to describe the adjustment
in depreciation charge made in
the year for vehicles sold at an
amount different to their net book
value at the date of sale (net of
attributable selling costs), divided
by the number of vehicles sold

wayneJ @BE - heck BE - you mean you are 'skimming' - I thought only analysts under Mifid2 did that?
BE11:50am

........ hm.

11:50 am
DM11:51am

One for the experts

IslandDweller Can't see used prices of vans rising - stricter emissions rules (such as London ULEZ) means older diesel vehicles won't be attractive
Forester Van rental is just about the best leading economic indicator you can get IMHO
BE11:51am

Jefferies, as also noted by @wayneJ over on the right.

BE11:51am

Conclusion: We've only had a chance to skim Northgate's statement, but it seems that the positive action on fleet management we sought in our last note (The pause before delivery......) is being taken. We argued that given our long held mistrust of the P&L (exposure to disposal profits) meant we'd rather see the group focus on managing the fleet to cash (real) than the accounting treatments of the P&L. We suspect lower short term disposal volumes as the group adjusts to a reworked fleet strategy (plan to optimise by holding vehicles 3-9 months longer) is the significant component of the steer that FY18 PBT is expected to fall 25% yoy (lower UK rental profits is also a factor as the unit stabilises). But our first response is that given the situation that the group's accounts have found themselves in, we've preferred to look through the P&L anyway (less vehicles to sell at high PPU will obviously impact the P&L) to focus on balance sheet and cash flow. News that the depreciation rates will be reviewed at year-end may again confuse the P&L further in future, but managing to optimise cash is for us the right strategy we've called for.

Miss Piggy @BE. DM: Fed minutes digest?
IslandDweller @Forester - and train commuter volumes. tfl tube figures are well down...
wayneJ So at least one bank claims the book value is understated - but that depends on the assumptions of the residual values - and the company has just told us that the residual values are difficult to achieve.

Miss Piggy yuck emojis on the right. I think I'll quit this room now.
11:55 am

BE11:56am

Welcome to the wonderful world of SEO.

BE11:59am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Group revs. came in at £74.2m in 4Q17 vs. cons of £79.2m for Q4 (-6%) and UBSe of £76.7m (-3%). FY17 adj. operating profit came in at £113.9m, +2% vs. cons., driven by gross margins at 74% (cons. at 73%) and distribution exp. down £5m YoY in 2017 to £29m.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Q4 insurance rev growth slowed down from 11% YoY in Q3 to +1% YoY in Q4 (vs. +9% in UBSe), and home services suffered from tough comps with revenues down -25% YoY in Q4 (vs. -12% in UBSe). Money was a bright spot at +15% YoY in Q4.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: The company guides to 6-7% end markets growth going forward, with 2018e rev. growth slower and adj. EBITDA for 2018e flat YoY (-9% to 2018e cons. expectations of £139m) as the company invests in mobile and optimizes customer journey.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We expect the market to react negatively to lower than cons. EBITDA guidance for 2018e. The company is due to present later today at 9.30am on results and strategy

BE12:01pm

MONY results were broadly in line. Revenues were below our forecasts, up 4% to £329.7m vs our £338.8m. However, EBITA grew 6% to £113.9m vs our £112.9m, and EPS was 16.9p vs our 16.7p. Dividend raised by 6%. Strong performance from Insurance, up by 12%, benefiting from an uplift in premiums. Money was up 3%, impacted by a weak market for savings products, and Home Services down 22%, as expected, given the lack of major collective switches. The key focus is outlook, where management flags £5m of additional cost, as it builds out engineering teams to improve site optimisation, while YTD trading is softer than expected at 4%. This points to downgrades of around £10m (vs our PBT £123.1m/18.3p), which would be -8% to 9%. We would expect a negative response, given an existing premium rating.

BE12:06pm

Sales - BAT posted organic growth of +2.9% for FY17, vs Bloomberg consensus of +3.4%. Of this, organic volume growth (combustibles + THPs) was -2.6% (vs the market of -3.5%). Reported revenue of £20,034mn came in 2% light of our expectations. The company generated revenue from NGPs of £397mn, or c. £500mn including RAI NGPs (vs consensus £550mn).
Operating profit - Adjusted operating profit came in at £7,993mn, broadly in line with GSe of £7,938mn. The operating margin reached 39.9%, ahead of GSe of 38.8%. EPS - BAT achieved adjusted diluted EPS of 284.4p in FY17, in line with consensus of 284p
Guidance - Management gave NGP revenue guidance of £1bn in 2018 and greater than £5bn by £22bn (unchanged).

BE12:06pm

Whilst the lighter organic revenue growth and NGP revenues vs consensus could be seen as disappointing, progress is still encouraging with Glo reaching 3.6% market share in Japan by the end of 2017. Since the national rollout of Glo (from October 2017), 50% of the overall tobacco heating category growth in Japan has been from Glo.
On combustibles, management highlight share gains, with market share up (excluding the US) by 110bps, which suggests organic growth fell short from price/mix.

BE12:08pm

The highlights of FY17 results were the much better than expected cash generation and the lower than expected IAS 19 pension
deficit. Guidance for FY18 EBIT is in line with our forecasts that had already assumed £1=$1.42, and EPS is a little better due to
a lower tax rate. We expect c.2-3% downgrades to FY18 consensus EPS to reflect FX, IFRS 15 and the new reporting structure.

BE12:08pm

FY18 outlook – a small organic decline and FX headwind
 We estimate BAE guidance for FY18 EPS inline with IFRS 15 and FX adjusted FY17 EPS of 42.1p implies a small organic
revenue and EBIT decline, offset by lower tax and interest charge.
 “Broadly unchanged” net debt guidance suggests a y/y decline in operating cash flow as the timing benefits of the advanced
Saudi support funding and VAT payments unwind.
 We estimate the mid-point of FY18 EBIT guidance implied by the divisional growth and margin guidance is £1.98bn which is
in line with our forecasts for £1.97bn. The guidance for interest charge is in line with our forecasts but the tax rate guidance
for 18% is c.400bps lower than we had expected.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

FY17 results - EBIT inline, EPS better and strong cash generation
 FY17 revenues of £19.6bn were c.1% below our forecasts. Group EBIT of £2,034m was line and EPS was c.2% ahead
 Cash generation was much better than we expected and net debt of £752m was significantly below our forecasts for £1.34bn.
 Book to bill was c.1x and the order book is flat y/y on a constant currency basis.
 The IAS 19 pension deficit is also down significantly at £3.9bn vs £5.9bn at H1 17, and the gap with the asset based pension
deficit of £2.1bn has closed significantly.
